When Ukrainian protesters forced out the country's president one year ago, ground zero was the central square in Kiev, known as Maidan.
The country's gone through a rough time since then, and there's still no resolution to the fighting in eastern Ukraine between the army and the separatists supported by Russia.
But over the weekend, thousands of civilians returned to the square to mark the anniversary and once again speak their minds.
NPR's Corey Flintoff has this audio postcard from Kiev.
People visit the Maidan at all hours.
Some leave flowers and light candles at makeshift memorials for protesters who died here last year.
Some come to lodge new protests and calls for help in a country that's beset by war and close to financial collapse.
(Singing in foreign language).
On this day, folksingers draw several hundred people around the foot of the monument to Ukrainian independence.
The square is lined with recruiting posters for the Ukrainian Army and festooned with rows of blue and yellow Ukrainian flags strung together.
It might be a festive atmosphere, except that many people are here to voice anxieties and discontents.
This is Diana Katyenko.
We do really not agree with some actions our president and our prime minister do, so - and we really ask them to change their politic because they're wrong with lots of action actually.
Katyenko is here with her mother and godmother.
They say they were here a year ago during the clashes when more than 100 people were killed.
They think President Poroshenko has compromised too much in his negotiations with Russia over the war in eastern Ukraine.
Judging from the signs people carry here, many of them want different things - jobs, protection for their savings, a few are even promoting their own new designs for Ukraine's flag.
But most of them join in when the national anthem is played.
(Singing in Ukrainian).
Somehow, all the different messages blend together for a few minutes - the voices of people who are just stopping by and those who look as if they can't bring themselves to leave.
(Speaking Ukrainian).
(Chanting in Ukrainian).
The chant is, ""Maidan lives, Maidan lives."" And that's one thing on which people here seem absolutely determined.
Corey Flintoff, NPR News.
When people in China pick up their smartphones each morning and check their messages, WeChat is most likely the app of choice.
The messaging program isn't well-known in the U.S., but in China it boasts 300 million users.
WeChat allows users to organize themselves into groups.
And NPR's Anthony Kuhn, in Beijing, says it's having a profound impact.
(Chanting in foreign language).
A group of college students are playing games.
They're getting to know each other at a leadership training session.
Each student here runs a nonprofit organization.
Each nonprofit forms its own circle or chat group on WeChat.
Yubien(ph) is doing the training.
He points to a long list of WeChat groups on his smartphone.
(Through translator) The group I use the most is the one with my colleagues in it.
At the start of each day, we use it to discuss the tasks we have to do.
This is where I post most of my stuff.
Michelle Ling is executive director of Black Apple Youth, the umbrella group of nonprofits that's hosting this leadership training.
She says Black Apple has 20 WeChat groups, each of which has many subgroups.
(Through translator) They're divided according to activities.
For example, we held a training group in August and all the participants formed a group.
Then we also have six groups representing different regions of the country, as well as one for overseas members.
China's government maintains restrictions on its citizens' ability to organize, but WeChat enables its users to link groups of up to 500 people into nationwide networks.
They can raise funds and mobilize members quickly.
Hu Yong is a scholar of new media at Beijing University.

He says together with China's popular microblogging app, Weibo, WeChat has given Chinese citizens a tool to exercise their constitutionally guaranteed rights to express themselves and form civic groups.
(Through translator) New media makes it possible for Chinese people to achieve a partial measure of freedom of speech and freedom of association.
Under the current circumstances, forming a non-governmental organization is very difficult.
Michelle Ling adds, though, that her groups take certain precautions when using WeChat.
(Through translator) We don't encourage our young people to get involved in excessively radical discourse that may affect our organization's future or take political positions that are too obvious.
Then there are people like Vancouver-based activist Li Yiping.
He wrote an online manifesto whose title can be roughly translated as ""Strategy For Regime Change."" The strategy is this - do not have a formal leadership structure that authorities can target.
Keep all political content off-line.
To outsiders, your WeChat group should just look like a bunch of citizens organizing dinner parties.
(Through translator) Through the use of this strategy, we've already broken through the Communist Party's ban on non-governmental political groups.
Behind the party's Iron Curtain, we have already found limitless space to develop.
They can't monitor, much less suppress, our form of organization.

When you hear words like that, spending your time based in Washington, going to the Pentagon then going abroad, how were people in Washington, particularly in the realm of politics and the military, react into those kinds of words?
Well, they - the words have certainly reverberated here in Washington, Farai, but I think there's primarily been a lot of push back both from politicians on Capitol Hill and from the Pentagon.
The Pentagon, essentially, implied that Sanchez is dealing with what they described as his own ghost, that he has been haunted by something.

You know, from the administration's perspective, I don't imagine his comments are likely to be taken that seriously, in large part, because Sanchez isn't the first retired senior military commander to really lash out about the Iraq strategy, and I suspect he won't be the last.
Let's go a little bit deeper into the trip you just took.
You spent time in Iraq with the Air Force and an army helicopter unit that evacuates wounded troops.
Balad is a place where you were actually detained by the U.S.
military.
How and why did that happen?
I think, Farai, it was more a function of bureaucratic mismanagement than anything else.
I was in Iraq ostensibly to look into how U.S.
troops are evacuated from the battlefield, so I spent time with various units.
One unit I was with was an Army helicopter unit that literally goes to the battlefield sites, takes up the wounded soldiers and ferries them to the hospital.
And one night it was a particularly nasty evening.
You could see tracer fire and RPG flashes all around as the helicopter landed.
They picked up an Iraqi soldier who was wounded, and loaded him on to the helicopter.
And we lifted off very quickly back to the hospital at Balad Air Base.
I followed the Army medic inside the emergency room.
He encouraged me to come.
But what happened was, once I was inside, an Air Force administrator, I think, panicked and she took me aside to ask for my identity.

And actually the Air Force, which is in charge of the hospital, had already cleared me to be inside of the hospital but she simply wasn't convinced, and so she had asked two armed guards to detain me and then to search me.
That whole process lasted about three hours, before I was released and before she did actually locate the paperwork.
But I really think it speaks to the kind of bureaucratic mishaps that happen within the Air Force in Iraq a lot.
And part of that reason is the Air Force Airmen only serve four-month tours in Iraq, and so you have so much turnover.
There's a lot of confusion.
And this officer, in particular, had just arrived to Iraq so she may not have been necessarily familiar with all of the procedures.
In addition to people who actually detained you were armed contractors, not actual troops.
Right.
How many different types of jobs, what kind of volume of jobs are contractors doing that the U.S.
military might have done in the past?

You know, Farai, we hear a lot about security contractors like Blackwater and others, but actually the overwhelming number of contractors in Iraq - we're talking about 180,000 people here now - are in fact low-skilled laborers, and most of them come from third-world countries like Sri Lanka, the Philippines, Pakistan, India.
And these are the people who do the laundry, and wash the dishes, and make the food, and do the construction jobs at the U.S.
military bases.
I spent quite a bit of time with one group of laborers from Sri Lanka.
They are paid about $20 a day for a 12-hour shift, working seven days a week.
And all of this cheap labor ultimately benefits very large U.S.
companies who manage these billion-dollar Pentagon contracts to kind of outsourcing of the war, if you will.
Finally, Guy, there was a Washington Post journalist killed, someone who was local but who was a staffer.
What is the sense that you get of how journalists aren't able to do their jobs in Iraq?
It's very difficult, Farai.

I think that as a reporter, in my experience having been embedded with the military, you are dependent on the military to help you see as much of the country as you can, and of course, they will show you the parts of the country that they want to show you and the things they want to show you.
That makes it very frustrating.
It makes it very frustrating to get a full picture of what's going on in Iraq.
But ultimately it is one of the very few ways to report on Iraq given the current circumstances.
It's almost impossible for even an Iraqi reporter, like this Washington Post correspondent, to go out freely, interview people, survey a scene, and come back safely and write a story.
It's very, very tragic.
